Issues.Title: Router tutorial: tour of heroes refers to non-existent code.
Issues.Body:
# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report ### Description **Router tutorial: tour of heroes** refers to non-existent code. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Follow the tutorial up to (and including) **Milestone 3: Heroes feature**. ### What's the affected URL?** [Router tutorial: tour of heroes](https://angular.io/guide/router-tutorial-toh) ### Reproduction Steps** 1. Complete the first two milestones. 2. Follow the instructions in [Add heroes functionality](https://angular.io/guide/router-tutorial-toh#add-heroes-functionality). 3. The [Route Parameters](https://angular.io/guide/router-tutorial-toh#route-parameters) section is where things start to get confusing. The text refers to this code ```html ``` but it doesn't seem to appear anywhere in the original Tour of Heroes tutorial; neither in [Part 4 (Services)](https://stackblitz.com/angular/dkjekblappg?file=src%2Fapp%2Fheroes%2Fheroes.component.html) nor in [Part 5 (In-App Navigation)](https://stackblitz.com/angular/lkeoljvavbl?file=src%2Fapp%2Fheroes%2Fheroes.component.html). 4. In the following section, [`ActivatedRoute` in action](https://angular.io/guide/router-tutorial-toh#activated-route-in-action), we're told to paste the following code in `ngOnInit()` ```typescript ngOnInit() { this.hero$ = this.route.paramMap.pipe( switchMap((params: ParamMap) => this.service.getHero(params.get('id'))) ); } ``` but this yields several compilation errors because neither the `hero$` property in `HeroDetailComponent` nor the `getHero` method in `HeroService` have been declared yet. (`getHero` is defined in Part 5 of the TOH Tutorial, but the page refers to Part 4.) The same section also contains this paragraph: > AsyncPipe handles the observable subscription and the component's hero property will be (re)set with the retrieved hero. However, `hero-detail.component.html` doesn't contain any references to `hero$`, nor does it contain the `async` pipe. It _does_ refer several times to the `hero` property, so I tried to replace these references with `(hero$ | async)` but this turns out to be illegal in the context of a two-way binding using `[(ngModel)]`. 5. The following section, [Navigating back to the list component](https://angular.io/guide/router-tutorial-toh#navigating-back-to-the-list-component), talks about the `HeroDetailComponent` "Back" button, but no such button exists in `hero-detail.component.html`. ### Expected vs Actual Behavior** It should be possible to follow along the instructions in this tutorial using the sample code. It seems that whoever wrote this tutorial was using a different version of the TOH tutorial. ## üì∑Screenshot ## üî• Exception or Error
## üåç Your Environment ### Browser info ### Anything else relevant?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Router tutorial: tour of heroes refers to non-existent code." (#40299)

Issues.Title: Using formControlName in <form> tag is throwing error in Angular 11 but works with <div>
Issues.Body:
**So, I am seeing a weird issue in Angular 11.0.5.
I have nested form group structure which was working in Angular 9.1.0

form formGroupName="Switch" *ngIf="rule?.controls?.Switch"  -- Works in Angular 9 but doesn't work in Angular 11.

But when i change the form tag to div tag, it starts working again.

div formGroupName="Switch" *ngIf="rule?.controls?.Switch"  /div -- Work in both Angular 9 & 11.**
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Using formControlName in <form> tag is throwing error in Angular 11 but works with <div>" (#40298)

Issues.Title: Get direct access to ng-content input
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request Make content that comes in via `ng-content` more easily accessible. ### Description I would like to be able to give content to a component like this: ```html {{ content }} ``` And then get direct access to the content inside my component, e.g. via an injection or a special template variable. I have a more detailed description of how this should work here: [Render string input of ng-content directly as HTML](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/64733677/render-string-input-of-ng-content-directly-as-html) (StackOverflow) This also includes a StackBlitz of how I would like to avoid to do it (see [get-input-of-ng-content-directly](https://stackblitz.com/edit/get-input-of-ng-content-directly)). ### Describe the solution you'd like I would like to use it in the template directly, something like this: ```html
``` Or inject it like this: ```typescript constructor(ngContentStuff: NgContent) ``` ### Describe alternatives you've considered In the StackBlitz example I am getting the content via `ng-content` in the template and than access it via `elementRef.nativeElement.textContent`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Get direct access to ng-content input" (#40293)

Issues.Title: ServiceWorker error for GoogleBot
Issues.Body:
Not really sure if this is an issue: this errors occurs on the client when GoogleBot visits, and when ServiceWorkerModule.register is being called.

Not sure yet if this affects indexing, but i would assume GoogleBot does not care about js errors.

The output from my logging:

`{
	"value": "Error: Rejected\n    at ServiceWorkerContainer.wrsParams.serviceWorkers.navigator.serviceWorker.register (<anonymous>:10:852)\n    at n._next (https://www.free-sudoku-puzzle.net/main.417f5bc5ef2630cdc7a3.js:1:591150)\n    at n.value (https://www.free-sudoku-puzzle.net/main.417f5bc5ef2630cdc7a3.js:1:23649)\n    at n.value (https://www.free-sudoku-puzzle.net/main.417f5bc5ef2630cdc7a3.js:1:22788)\n    at n.value (https://www.free-sudoku-puzzle.net/main.417f5bc5ef2630cdc7a3.js:1:21676)\n    at n.value (https://www.free-sudoku-puzzle.net/main.417f5bc5ef2630cdc7a3.js:1:21306)\n    at n.value (https://www.free-sudoku-puzzle.net/main.417f5bc5ef2630cdc7a3.js:1:72357)\n    at n.value (https://www.free-sudoku-puzzle.net/main.417f5bc5ef2630cdc7a3.js:1:21306)\n    at n.value (https://www.free-sudoku-puzzle.net/main.417f5bc5ef2630cdc7a3.js:1:20214)\n    at n.value (https://www.free-sudoku-puzzle.net/main.417f5bc5ef2630cdc7a3.js:1:594348)",
	"ua": "Mozilla/5.0 AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko; compatible; Googlebot/2.1; +http://www.google.com/bot.html) Chrome/87.0.4280.90 Safari/537.36",
}`

The shortened code of my module:

`@NgModule({
  declarations: [
    AppComponent, NavigationComponent
  ],
  imports: [
    BrowserModule,
    SharedModule.forRoot(),
    HttpClientModule,
	...,
    ServiceWorkerModule.register('ngsw-worker.js', { enabled: environment.production })
  ],
  providers: [],
  bootstrap: [AppComponent]
})
export class AppModule { }`

# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
 This feature request is for @angular/root



### Description
Recently, after discovering many programming techniques, I found that all techniques are used **annotation**
like we sees in the photo           
But I found that **Angular** put it in the **appModule** file or in a separated file but all the root are in the same places          
That is why I said, why don't we work on making the technology similar to the rest of the technologies 
for exemple if your component is a page in your template you can add @({root:"/RootName"}) as a decorator to the component class
         
```
// this the decorator 
@Root({ root: "/todo" })
@Component({
  selector: 'app-todos',
  templateUrl: './todos.component.html'
})
export class TodosComponent implements OnInit {
  newTodo: any;
  todos: Todo[]
...
```


### Describe the solution you'd like
I have not a Solution üòìüòì

Issues.Title: refactor(router): refactor and simplify router RxJS chains
Issues.Body:
## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [ ] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [ ] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [x] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

## Other information

I refactored and simplified some RxJS usage in the Router package in order to reduce its size and increase performance. Unfortunatelly, I'm not able to verify the package size because `node ./scripts/build/build-packages-dist.js` fails on my system for some reason.

The biggest changes are these:
- I replaced all accurences of `first()` with `take(1)` because [without any parameter it's the same just `take(1)`](https://github.com/ReactiveX/rxjs/blob/master/src/internal/operators/first.ts#L89-L91) (same with `last` and `takeLast()`). (**I'll need to check if these scenarios are tested, it might be just luck that the tests are passing because of https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42345969/take1-vs-first/42346203#42346203**)
- Some custom operators were wrapped with another function even though they didn't need `source` Observable.
- `from([x, y, z])` is the same as `of(x, y, z)` and using `of()` should be faster (I'll need to test this).

There are some other usecases that seem suspicious like using `from().pipe(mergeAll())` should be the same as using just `merge()` but I'll need to be able to run `build-packages-dist.js` to make sure it generates smaller package.

Bundle size `main-es2015` in `cli-hello-world-lazy-rollup` integration test dropped from expected `218507` to `217825`.
Bundle size `main-es2015` in `cli-hello-world-lazy` integration test dropped from expected `241837` to `241139`.
So both bundles are cca 700 B smaller.

I'm not sure about the [removed records in `bundle.golden_symbols.json`](https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/40290/files#diff-0ea07045c567fb07c48994161c0a3bfa5bd1a676bc484d0fd8d3f9c5c2bc5d8d). It has probably something to do with this change https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/40290/files#diff-1706bbbdd4dda445171e80023d67b54f1aa77a457d6b81b6815239113fd34decR62-R66 but I'm not sure why.

I didn't make any change to existing tests because this should not break anything.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(router): refactor and simplify router RxJS chains" (#40290)

Issues.Title: Angular 11 and GoogleBot
Issues.Body:
Angular 11 is, out of the box, not indexable by GoogleBot ... 
I have few websites (on older angular versions) running that are perfectly indexed by GoogleBot, and that actually have good indexing and search performance. A new Angular 11 application will simply return 404 in the "Test live url" utility of Google Search Console. 

Result page in search console:
https://photos.app.goo.gl/eg2doJdMuhZioiMr8

The page at "/" IS indexable, but any other route fails ...

Could this be related to polyfills? 

Things i already tried: 
- static module loading instead of lazy loading for route
- removing pwa/service workers

I am now going to try and get client-side error logging in, to see if any errors are raised when googlebot visits.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Angular 11 and GoogleBot" (#40283)

Issues.Title: refactor(compiler-cli): `FileSystem` interface break up
Issues.Body:
This interface now extends `ReadonlyFileSystem` which in turn
extends `PathManipulation`. This means consumers of these
interfaces can be more specific about what is needed, and so
providers do not need to implement unnecessary methods.

# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description

<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit:--> 
On the page [Adding Navigation](https://angular.io/start/start-routing), there is a section where we need to update the products by adding a productId. The statement reads, and I quote:
> Update the *ngFor directive to read as follows. This statement instructs Angular to iterate over the items in the products array and assigns each index in the array to the productId variable when iterating over the list.

But there is nothing below that actually does this. Was this intentional? If it was, maybe rephrase the sentence to mean that **you** need to do it.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

### What's the affected URL?**
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit:--> 
https://angular.io/start/start-routing

### Expected vs Actual Behavior**

Issues.Title: Headers getting removed for Microsoft Graph API in iPad browsers
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/common/http ### Is this a regression? I am not sure about this as this is the first time we are implementing it with the below mentioned setup ### Description We have an Ionic/Angular PWA app with Microsoft Azure login. For login we have used [@azure/msal-angular](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@azure/msal-angular) v1.0.0 plugin. After login we fetch 2 access tokens and store it in localStorage. One access token for normal app API and another for Microsoft Graph API where we fetch a members list from Azure Active Directory Group and use it in the app. We are using HttpClient from @angular/common/http package to make these API calls. All the API calls works fine for desktop browsers but the problem is while sending the Graph API call https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/groups/group-id/members from iPad browsers(tested in Safari, Chrome and Firefox), the headers are getting removed, so the access token is not passed resulting in 401 Unauthorized error. **This issue is happening exclusively for Graph API call in iPad browsers**. Kindly refer below screenshots. _**Normal API call with access token in headers**_ ![Screen Shot 2020-12-30 at 12 56 29 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13345195/103348672-bb363400-4ac0-11eb-99ea-48d7786ee414.png) **_Graph API call with no headers_** ![Screen Shot 2020-12-30 at 12 56 53 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13345195/103348864-49aab580-4ac1-11eb-82f4-667441c62e35.png) **_Resulting in 401 Unauthorized error_** ![Screen Shot 2020-12-30 at 12 57 45 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13345195/103348977-9a221300-4ac1-11eb-881b-10a08c5d1a8b.png) ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Due to the app architecture it will be difficult to share minimal reproduction of the issue but I'll try if possible and update the stackblitz or repo URL here. ## üî• Exception or Error

# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
This is for @angular/service-worker

### Description
As [Angular Service worker doc](https://angular.io/guide/service-worker-config) described:

> You can also emulate a third strategy, staleWhileRevalidate, which returns cached data (if available), but also fetches fresh data from the network in the background for next time.

If we can receive the `fresh data` in our code, we can compare the `fresh data` with the `cache data `that the application is using, and to do sth like: **Show content from cache, update cache in background and show updated content as soon as it arrives**


### Describe the solution you'd like
I would like to do this in my code like:
```
this.serviceWorker.subscribe((data, url)=> {
  if (data != old data) {
    update application
  }
})
```

Issues.Title: @angular/compiler-cli downleveling decorators possibly causing RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded with isReferencedAliasDeclaration
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/compiler-cli version >=10 ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this issue was not happening was: 9 It started happening in Angular 10 with the introduction of decorator downleveling: ``` compiler-cli: downlevel angular decorators to static properties (#37382) (323651b), closes #30586 #30106 #30586 #30141 ``` PR: https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/37382 ### Description We just did an upgrade from Angular 9->11 and started seeing this problem in our biggest application when we run ng serve. We have a monorepo setup with Nx. After the upgrade we were able to start 3 other applications that are a little bit smaller than previously mentioned one. Since the error is quite unclear i started investigating what could be the cause and found only one issue report similar to this one here: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/18792 But that seemed to be an issue that was caused in their own setup. I also looked if we had anything similar, but with no luck. I also tried doing divide and conquer approach removing some modules from the application and that made it work. However there was no exact rule which modules work and which dont, the distribution was quite random expect one thing if i made the app smaller, then it worked(by removing bigger modules). Next on my list was to add some logging in `patchAliasReferenceResolutionOrDie` for the nodes that were being traversed and I did not see any circular dependency that would cause an infinite recursion. Then i tried adjusting the implementation of `isReferencedAliasDeclaration` and was able to make this work by changing this part here: ```ts // Before emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration = function(node, ...args) { if (isAliasImportDeclaration(node) && referencedAliases.has(node)) { return true; } return originalReferenceResolution.call(emitResolver, node, ...args); }; // After emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration = function(node, checkChildren) { if (isAliasImportDeclaration(node) && referencedAliases.has(node)) { return true; } return originalReferenceResolution.call(emitResolver, node, checkChildren); }; ``` https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/packages/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.ts#L87 This change was made so that `isReferencedAliasDeclaration` looks exactly like the typescript implementation https://sourcegraph.com/github.com/microsoft/TypeScript@3eaa7c65f6f076a08a5f7f1946fd0df7c7430259/-/blob/src/compiler/checker.ts#L36179-36192 And this fixed the issue. My 2 cents on why this fixed it is better explained when looking at compiled code of the function ```js // Before emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration = function (node) { var args = []; for (var _i = 1, _len = arguments.length; _i < _len; _i++) { args[_i - 1] = arguments[_i]; } if (isAliasImportDeclaration(node) && referencedAliases.has(node)) { return true; } return originalReferenceResolution.call.apply(originalReferenceResolution, tslib_1.__spread([emitResolver, node], args)); }; // After emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration = function (node, checkChildren) { if (isAliasImportDeclaration(node) && referencedAliases.has(node)) { return true; } return originalReferenceResolution.call(emitResolver, node, checkChildren); }; ``` During tree traversal `isReferencedAliasDeclaration` in each call is creating its own local array copying the arguments and then spreading that back again to original implementation, so i suppose after certain number of calls the memory just gets over allowed threshold and breaks. ## üî• Exception or Error 



Error: RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded
    at Set.has ()
    at Object.emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration (/monorepo/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.js:84:69)
    at Object.emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration (/monorepo/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.js:87:53)
    at Object.emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration (/monorepo/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.js:87:53)
    at Object.emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration (/monorepo/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.js:87:53)
    at Object.emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration (/monorepo/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.js:87:53)
    at Object.emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration (/monorepo/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.js:87:53)
    at Object.emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration (/monorepo/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.js:87:53)
    at Object.emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration (/monorepo/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.js:87:53)
    at Object.emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration (/monorepo/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.js:87:53)
    at Object.emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration (/monorepo/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.js:87:53)
    at Object.emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration (/monorepo/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.js:87:53)
    at Object.emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration (/monorepo/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.js:87:53)

Issues.Title: Docs: Add 'Adding reactivity' section to 'Try It' in the 'Getting Started' guide
Issues.Body: # üìö Docs or angular.io bug report ### Description In the **[Try It](https://angular.io/start)** section the shopping app that is being created is small and doesn't fully show the power of Angular's (with RxJS) reactivity system. - What do I mean by that? In the current app, the user can buy things, and they get added to the cart. On click of the buy button, the app shows just an alert that the item was bought and that's all (the item is added in the cart items array in the service in the background). If we want to show the number of the cart items on the **top bar component** we cannot do it by just showing the length of the cart items array. Like this: ```ts export class TopBarComponent { count = this.cart.getItems().length; constructor(private cart: CartService) {} } ``` ```html shopping_cart Checkout {{ count }} ``` It won't work, because when we buy another item the change detection will not be triggered for that component, because Angular isn't listening to that value. And here is where RxJS comes into play. What we can do is to introduce a `BehaviourSubject` in the cart service and explain it and the pros of using RxJS for this kind of use-cases. It can be a simple pattern like this: ```ts export class CartService { private items = new BehaviorSubject([]); items$ = this.items.asObservable().pipe(distinctUntilChanged()); cartCount$ = this.items$.pipe(map(items => items.length)); addToCart(product: Product): void { const currentItems = this.items.value; this.items.next([...currentItems, product]); } clearCart(): void { this.items.next([]); } } ``` and use it like this: ```ts @Component({ ... changeDetection: ChangeDetectionStrategy.OnPush }) export class TopBarComponent { cartCount$ = this.cartService.cartCount$; constructor(private cartService: CartService) {} } ``` ```html shopping_cart Checkout ({{ cartCount$ | async }}) ``` I also have created a repo with the app and it uses the RxJS functionalities to add reactivity to the app. [Try It App with RxJS.](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-hhwc8c?file=src/app/cart.service.ts) Also, if this gets added, we can also introduce the dev to `async` pipe, `ChangeDetectionStrategy.OnPush` and Immutability
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Docs: Add 'Adding reactivity' section to 'Try It' in the 'Getting Started' guide" (#40275)

Issues.Title: docs(router): Clarify how to clear secondary routes
Issues.Body:
The example for clearing secondary outlets currently only works because
the named outlet appears at the root of the application's route config.
If developers follow this example with an outlet that is not at the
root level, they will not be able to close the outlet.
This commit updates the example to provide a more robust way
of clearing the outlet from the activated outlet component
as well as providing a warning about how the commands are applied.

Lastly, there is a small bit of guidance provided for developers who
might want to explore the ability to close an outlet from any location
in the app, without needing to be aware of the activated route.
An example of this can be found here:
https://stackblitz.com/edit/close-outlet-from-anywhere

resolves #13523

Question to reviewers: 
I wonder if I should omit the last bit about closing the outlet using `navigateByUrl` because it goes beyond the common use-cases of just closing the outlet from either the parent that opened it or the activated child itself.
It's quite an advanced topic and complicated to explain but may still be something that devs want to do.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "docs(router): Clarify how to clear secondary routes" (#40272)

# üêû bug report ### Affected Package This issue is caused by @angular/compiler ### Is this a regression? This did not work as far back as v. 9. ### Description When installing a custom web element library (specifically @microsoft/fast-components) through node with the custom elements schema enabled, the custom web elements render fine in development mode. However, when building the application in the default "production" configuration with `buildOptimizer` set to true, the custom elements will cause a "call stack size exceeded" error. This error does not happen normally on these elements. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Pull the repro from [here](https://github.com/tgoze/ng-build-optimizer-custom-web-el-repro). This is a base Angular 11 project with @microsoft/fast-components installed. The components are included as instructed on this [site](https://www.fast.design/docs/integrations/angular). ### Normal behavior: 1. Pull the repo 2. Run `npm i` 3. Run `npm start` 4. Open localhost:4200 5. See a simple textbox and radio button rendered and no console errors ### Reproduce error: 1. Run `npm start-prod` 2. Open localhost:5005 3. Observe the console error and the radio button un-rendered If `buildOptimizer` in angular.json for the production mode is set to `false` the error will not occur for `npm start-prod`. ## üî• Exception or Error

Issues.Title: Resolve ~ to node_modules universally (Also in ng-packagr)?
Issues.Body:
In sass we can do this:

```
@import ~/somepackage.css
```

Instead of:

```
@import ../../../../../../somepackage.css
```

But we can't do this (For example):

```
  styleUrls: ['~@fireflysemantics/help-center-css/components/topic-meta.component.css']

```

We have to do this:

```
  styleUrls: ['../../../../node_modules/@fireflysemantics/help-center-css/components/topic-meta.component.css']
```

It would be nice if we could use `~` throughout as something that just points to `node_modules` ...
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Resolve ~ to node_modules universally (Also in ng-packagr)?" (#19703)

Issues.Title: build: update sass to version 1.32.0
Issues.Body:
[![WhiteSource Renovate](https://app.renovatebot.com/images/banner.svg)](https://renovatebot.com)

This PR contains the following updates:

| Package | Change | Age | Adoption | Passing | Confidence |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| [sass](https://togithub.com/sass/dart-sass) | [`1.30.0` -> `1.32.0`](https://renovatebot.com/diffs/npm/sass/1.30.0/1.32.0) | [![age](https://badges.renovateapi.com/packages/npm/sass/1.32.0/age-slim)](https://docs.renovatebot.com/merge-confidence/) | [![adoption](https://badges.renovateapi.com/packages/npm/sass/1.32.0/adoption-slim)](https://docs.renovatebot.com/merge-confidence/) | [![passing](https://badges.renovateapi.com/packages/npm/sass/1.32.0/compatibility-slim/1.30.0)](https://docs.renovatebot.com/merge-confidence/) | [![confidence](https://badges.renovateapi.com/packages/npm/sass/1.32.0/confidence-slim/1.30.0)](https://docs.renovatebot.com/merge-confidence/) |

---

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>sass/dart-sass</summary>

### [`v1.32.0`](https://togithub.com/sass/dart-sass/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#​1320)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/sass/dart-sass/compare/1.30.0...1.32.0)

-   Deprecate passing non-`%` numbers as lightness and saturation to `hsl()`,
    `hsla()`, `color.adjust()`, and `color.change()`. This matches the CSS
    specification, which also requires `%` for all lightness and saturation
    parameters. See [the Sass website][color-units] for more details.

-   Deprecate passing numbers with units other than `deg` as the hue to `hsl()`,
    `hsla()`, `adjust-hue()`, `color.adjust()`, and `color.change()`. Unitless
    numbers _are_ still allowed here, since they're allowed by CSS. See [the Sass
    website][color-units] for more details.

-   Improve error messages about incompatible units.

-   Properly mark some warnings emitted by `sass:color` functions as deprecation
    warnings.

##### Dart API

-   Rename `SassNumber.valueInUnits()` to `SassNumber.coerceValue()`. The old name
    remains, but is now deprecated.

-   Rename `SassNumber.coerceValueToUnit()`, a shorthand for
    `SassNumber.coerceValue()` that takes a single numerator unit.

-   Add `SassNumber.coerceToMatch()` and `SassNumber.coerceValueToMatch()`, which
    work like `SassNumber.coerce()` and `SassNumber.coerceValue()` but take a
    `SassNumber` whose units should be matched rather than taking the units
    explicitly. These generate better error messages than `SassNumber.coerce()`
    and `SassNumber.coerceValue()`.

-   Add `SassNumber.convertToMatch()` and `SassNumber.convertValueToMatch()`,
    which work like `SassNumber.coerceToMatch()` and
    `SassNumber.coerceValueToMatch()` except they throw exceptions when converting
    unitless values to or from units.

-   Add `SassNumber.compatibleWithUnit()`, which returns whether the number can be
    coerced to a single numerator unit.

</details>

# üöÄ Feature request

### Description
We have many libs and apps in our monorepo. The problem is that most settings for libs in angular.json are identical, same for apps. We have few thousand lines of code in our angular.json, but it could be greatly reduced if we have base settings which can be overrided.

### Describe the solution you'd like
Add base settings for all libs/apps in angular.json which can be overrided by app or lib itself.

Issues.Title: AngularJS => Angular migration and ng-annotate
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request

### Description

Pretty much these other issues explain the motivations for my feature request: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/6873 by @yjaaidi and https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/3722 by @Itrulia

I'm migrating an app from AngularJs to Angular, and even when building for production I'm needing to specify `--optimization=false` because otherwise, the AngularJs parts of my app won't work. The reason is when using Angular CLI there is no way of including `ng-annotate` as part of the pipeline for the AngularJs bits.

What is the 2021 way of using ng-annotate for hybrid applications?

Thanks.

### Describe the solution you'd like
I would like a "plugins" section where I could specify "ng-annotate" and only for files that match a regex (the AngularJs files).

### Describe alternatives you've considered
I've considered:
1. **Ejecting the configuration and not using ng-cli.** I don't like this solution as I want to use Angular CLI and reduce customizations (so upcoming upgrades are smoother).
1. **Running ng-annotate on each of the Angular files by hand, and permanently replacing the original files.** But it's rather involved, I'd need to write a script that:
    - Removes the imports from the top of my files (because ng-annotate doesn't like "imports/exports" in non-module files).
    - Runs ng-annotate in each one, redirecting the output to a file, then swapping the files.
1. **Continuing to use the non-optimized version of my product in production**. My company's product is quite large, and it is taking several seconds to download and bootstrap, so this is exactly what I want to avoid.
1. **Using a custom webpack config prepended to ng-cli's one.** I found it [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/59302237/how-to-use-ng-annotate-with-hybrid-app-based-on-angular-cli).

So far it looks like number 4 is what I'm going to try, otherwise doing number 2. Unless there is already a better solution I have not considered.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "AngularJS => Angular migration and ng-annotate" (#19692)

Issues.Title: feat(google-maps): add heatmap support
Issues.Body:
Adds support for rendering heatmaps on the `google-map` component using the `map-heatmap-layer` directive. The directive is mostly a direct wrapper around the `google.maps.visualization.HeatmapLayer` class, except for the fact that it also accepts a `LatLngLiteral`, whereas the Google Maps class only accepts `LatLng` objects. I decided to add some logic to convert them automatically, because creating `LatLng` requires the Maps API to have been loaded which can lead to race conditions if it's being loaded lazily.

![Example](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4450522/103477692-e45d0a00-4dc9-11eb-9f92-6a8f7b2c4614.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(google-maps): add heatmap support" (#21489)

Issues.Title: feat(material/datepicker): add support for cancel/apply buttons
Issues.Body:
Adds support for projecting in "Cancel" and "Apply" buttons in `mat-datepicker` and `mat-date-range-picker`. Doing so will change the behavior of the datepicker so that the user has to explicitly accept a value after they've clicked on it. The consumption is as follows:

```
<mat-datepicker>
  <mat-datepicker-actions>
    <button mat-button matDatepickerCancel>Cancel</button>
    <button mat-raised-button color="primary" matDatepickerApply>Apply</button>
  </mat-datepicker-actions>
</mat-datepicker>
```

The result looks like this:
![Example](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4450522/103455069-5b26d400-4cf2-11eb-8919-5f389c2506cb.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(material/datepicker): add support for cancel/apply buttons" (#21487)

Issues.Title: help(Datepicker): Handle navigation by keyboard through calendar months
Issues.Body:
#### What are you trying to do?

I'm trying to find a way to handle navigation by keyboard through calendar months. Using a tab key on my keyboard I'm able to switch calendar view to the previous/next month, but I don't found any events that can emit any info about this process.

Additional info: I use custom **calendar header** + **mat-calendar**

#### What troubleshooting steps have you tried?

I have tried to subscribe to the calendar stateChanges subject. But there no info about the current/previous/next month date. Active date - it is a date which one is selected.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24374130/103411947-9a7ee480-4b7b-11eb-9bf9-efe8181aac97.png)
On the left side - the date navigated by a key tab. At the right side - selected (current date)

I saw PR https://github.com/angular/components/pull/3655, but there are no events to inform the user about view changes.

#### Reproduction

Easy can be reproduced here with the first calendar example.
https://material.angular.io/components/datepicker/examples

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open calendar.
2. Use the tab to move to the calendar.
3. User arrows on the keyboard to change the day.
  
#### Environment

- Angular: 10
- CDK/Material: 10
- Browser(s): Google Chrome
- Operating System: Windows 10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "help(Datepicker): Handle navigation by keyboard through calendar months" (#21485)

Issues.Title: bug(MatSelect): NVDA announce 'table' when select options opened
Issues.Body:
When opening `mat-select` element  NVDA screen reader announce `table` before announcing the `list`.

#### Reproduction

See the official example from material documentation. 

Steps to reproduce:
1. Click on the mat-select 
2. When the options opened NVDA announce `table` and then `list`.
 
 
#### Expected Behavior
`table` should not be announced.

#### More details

- This is a new issue. In Material V10 it's Ok. (checked also in the documentation of v10)
- Faced it with NVDA
- Happened in Chrome, not in Firefox.

#### Environment

- Angular: V11
- CDK/Material: V11
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Screen reader: NVDA
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(MatSelect): NVDA announce 'table' when select options opened " (#21480)

Issues.Title: update to google fonts version 2
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

now when you run `ng add @angular/materia` and select yes for `Set up global Angular Material typography styles?` it adds version 1 of google fonts, while now there is a newer version

most importantly it doesn't include the `<link rel="preconnect" href="https://fonts.gstatic.com">` that should makes improvement for loading the fonts and reducing First Contentful Paint time according to [web.dev](https://web.dev/uses-rel-preconnect/)

#### Use Case

i'm not sure how this works, but currently the output is

```
<link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Roboto:300,400,500&display=swap" rel="stylesheet">
```

but it should be

```
<link rel="preconnect" href="https://fonts.gstatic.com">
<link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Roboto:wght@300;400;500&display=swap" rel="stylesheet">
```

if anyone can point me to the right direction i can do the PL myself
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "update to google fonts version 2" (#21478)

Issues.Title: bug(Angular Material 11 Samples): Sample projects don't work forked locally
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction
Steps to reproduce:
1. Got to sample input component page https://material.angular.io/components/input/overview
2. Click on the "Edit basic inputs example in StackBlitz"
3. Sample app works fine
4. Download code locally: (Fork the project,  Connect repository, clone the repo locally)
5. In the local project folder run "npm install"
6. run "npm run start"
7. in browser go to http://localhost:4200/
8. App does not render (shows "loading Current build: 11.0.3")

Same behavior with other Angular Material 11 sample projects
Same steps with Angular Material 10 samples work fine
Noe: If I change the index.html content to place the component directive inside the "body" element directly, it renders, but the formatting is not applied. 
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

At step 8 I expect to see the same behavior as I see in Stackblitz sample or with Angular Material 10 local app
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11194908/103229835-e45c9600-4901-11eb-8b19-356349c06380.png)



#### Actual Behavior

See step 8
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11194908/103229736-ad868000-4901-11eb-80b4-5d42af058c28.png)


#### Environment

- Angular: 11
- CDK/Material: 11
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows
